title: Unravelling Multi-stage Formation and Deformation Events of RE-rich and RE-poor Anhydrite via Hyperspectral Cathodoluminescence Mapping and Analysis
content: A JXA-8530F field emission electron probe microanalyzer (EPMA) equipped with wavelength and energy dispersive spectrometry, together with cathodoluminescence (CL) spectrometer [1] has been used to investigate anhydrite-calcite mineral associations from the SWAN Iron ore-Copper-Gold (IOCG) and skarn deposit, Mt Elliot, Queensland (Australia). The studied drill core sample contains late-stage pink felsic dykes overwritten by Na-metasomatism (albite, K-feldspar, magnetite and accessory apatite) and the primary Cu-Au mineralization in a vug filled with coarse-grained anhydrite, calcite, magnetite, chalcopyrite, pyrite in millimeter sizes and accessory fine-grained wollastonite and titanite. The mineralization is considered to have formed at 1520 Â±6 Ma based on dating the coarse euhedral allanite (Ca,REE)2(Fe,Ti) (Al,Fe)2Si3O12(OH)) overgrown with chalcopyrite. Allanite ages are in good agreement of the accepted age for the Mt. Elliott deposit and neighboring igneous intrusions [2]. REE were mobilized and deposited by the same magmatic-hydrothermal fluid that precipitated the Cu-sulfides and the anhydrite resulted from the elevated heat flux from the igneous activity in the region [2].
